text: Patient: Berries and <____>. Doctor: High fiber, low fat? Patient: Yes. As much as I can. Doctor: And you’re in good shape where you don’t have a big belly or anything like that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So that’s good. Patient: And so the likelihood of what you’re seeing reoccurring is is is it high, minimum? Doctor: I would say, I would say based on so far minimum. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And if we go a year and find it’s still undetectable, uh then I think that uh that chances are very good that if it does reoccur that we can control it. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: I would say if it goes beyond a year I would say the risk is minimal and it continues to decrease.

text: Patient: Uh, you know, I am, uh, there, there was a few times whereas I felt like, uh, some pressure up here, and I just felt very lethargic, and, um, I took some, um, some aspirin- Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh, or Tylenol, and that seemed to, you know, put me back in a normal state. Doctor: How are you doing just overall, just the anxiety, and sort of in the past you had some issues with that. Does that kind of seem like it’s controlled or-? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah. That’s, that’s more controlled. I think, you know, since, since I’ve been retired, I haven’t really had, other than flare-ups sometimes with my son, but for the most part, uh, you know, I’m pretty, you know, level minded. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any new pain anywhere? Patient: No uh. Well, every once in a while, I get like a stiffness in my thighs. Doctor: Okay. When you’re doing something or just anytime? Patient: Every once in a while. Uh, it just, it just pops up. Doctor: And it’s in both thighs or one or-? Patient: Uh, sometimes it’s in both. Normally, it’s in both.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. text: Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Once you (makes sound) Family Member: So, so. Is this going to make him sleepless, like you said a little more energy? Doctor: No, no, it’s only going to help with pain and I think when you get off the Xtandi you’ll actually have more energy because no matter what that Xtandi is making you tired. Patient: Well my energy level isn’t bad. Doctor: Yeah, to you, but we’ve got this one over here going “Heh?” (Chuckles) Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active. Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. text: Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
